tweets.content: @oditoronto: Would be keen to hear about the global state of investment in IT at local level. Has a big impact on cities' capacity to be "smart" #IODC16
@MalickLingani: #IODC16 : Global Goals, Local inpact. GODAN now in room D. @godanSec @mbakatre @dianaszpotowiczpic.twitter.com/gWXFgjcMaQ

@GlobalIntegrity: Excited to learn how the @opendatacharter is connecting the dots between global principles and local practices. #IODC16 #OpenDataCharter

info:
In this panel, open data female leaders reflected about how using Open Data to achieve Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) around the world using IODC15 Open Data Roadmap.
All leaders convened on the role of open data as change-driver and remarked the need of policies to make a real impact through the use of the data. Also, they raised some issues such as: open washing, internet access, literacy, racial and gender discrimination or authoritarian regimes that put open data at risk. Some of the key messages were:

session.description: Open data has been prominently discussed in major global commitments this past year. From the the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, COPS 21 and Anti-Corruption Summit, data has been central to the political debate. However, is this really making a positive change in people’s lives on the ground? The...Read more

conference_notes:
In this panel, open data female leaders reflected about how using Open Data to achieve Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) around the world using IODC15 Open Data Roadmap. All leaders convened on the role of open data as change-driver and remarked the need of policies to make a real impact through the use of the data. Also, they raised some issues such as: open washing, internet access, literacy, racial and gender discrimination or authoritarian regimes that put open data at risk. Some of the key messages were:
  • Ania Calderón (Office of the President of Mexico) : “The success of open data policies is not only related with the technical part, it also requires political actions and implications from inside and outside the organization. Also, it implies changing the way we do policy-making. We need to acknowledge that we are living in the age of citizens. Governments alone will not be able to face all the challenges of today”.
  • Karin Christiansen (Open Knowledge) : “Nowadays, open data doesn’t improve people’s lives, but such a difficult goal is going to be very difficult to achieve without open data”.
  • Anne Jellema (World Wide Web Foundation): “Unless we tackle social challenges, open data is at risk of becoming an openness island in an increasingly authoritarian and closed world”.
  • Jeni Tennison (Open Data Institute) : “I have a positive view about the current impact of open data, and there are many examples where open data is already helping people every day, such as newspapers with highcharts, citymapper, re-use for statistics, etc.”.
name: Global Goals, Local Impact
